content: This is more of a request as to how I should structure this / if this is a good idea. I found that defining sort in terms of sort_embedding was 'cleaner' than the other way around, but since sort is so widely used, is that a good idea?

Tristan Figueroa-Reid said:

This is more of a request as to how I should structure this / if this is a good idea. I found that defining sort in terms of sort_embedding was 'cleaner' than the other way around, but since sort is so widely used, is that a good idea?

(I have not made any theorems because of this question yet, which is why the PR is a draft.)

Tristan Figueroa-Reid said:

Yakov Pechersky said:

Not sure what you mean by ordered frequency, and I couldn't figure it out from your example. The list in your example, I would have assumed would give (5, 4, 3) since the first item it encounters is a 7.

Oh yes - I mean as it would order the list first then get the frequency of items, though I suppose sorting it first is much better than a specific definition for this.

YaÃ«l Dillies said:

What do you want to do with this frequency distribution? I suspect this is an #xy problem

It might be, but it's for the weight of a semistandard Young Tableau.

Also, I'm not using sort_with_antisymmetry for anything, but sort_embedding has promising usage.
(My XY for sort_embedding is described in the above-forwarded message. I planned to have a method for Finsupp that returns a List of its values if the type on Finsupp has an instance of a total order, so the call to sort_embedding would map each element to a Prod of the element and its frequency, sort by the element, and map to the frequency.)
I'm missing the context for this PR. How/where do you want to use this?

Johan Commelin said:

I'm missing the context for this PR. How/where do you want to use this?

I specifically want to use this to map a multiset to a Prod of the original value and its frequency, sort the multiset by the original values, then map it by the frequency. The request for this pull request comes from the need to sort a multiset of Prods by only one of its values.
(To clarify, that is for getting the weight of a Semistandard Young Tableau)

That's a nice application (-;

Do you already have a formal definition of those weights in a place where I could take a look at them?

Johan Commelin said:

That's a nice application (-;

Do you already have a formal definition of those weights in a place where I could take a look at them?

Unfortunately not! I made the definition prematurely, but now that I write this, I noticed that my constraint on f is too strong. (f should only have a domain of the elements currently in the Multiset)
If you do re-implement sort in terms of some auxiliary sortEmbedding, make sure to keep the old docstring, or at least the mention of merge sort.
You can make the constraint be that s -> X is injective, where s is your multiset, since multiset can be coerced to a Sort.
I suggest that you first formalize more about weights, and that will guide what the lower level stuff should look like.
